### Introduction
Our approach overcomes these problems by providing real peer-to-peer communication only relying on already existent infrastructure.
We deploy end-to-end encryption by using a public key method based on OpenPGP.
In our implementation users assign public OpenPGP keyrings to telephone numbers on their mobile device, which can be used to encrypt and authenticate a direct VoIP conversation.
Instead of relying on classic VoIP providers, like Skype, we guarantee permanent peer-to-peer connections between the devices.
The main issue in peer-to-peer communications is the addressing of other devices.
Thus, we use the existing mobile phone numbers as identifiers to exchange public IP addresses and selected ports by utilizing SMS.
Previously proposed VoIP end-to-end encryption rely on a SIP provider to identify other devices, while our approach does not require the creation of other accounts.
Our method utilizes OpenPGP keyrings to establish a TLS connection without relying on central Certificate Authorities.
This TLS connection is used to establish a VoIP session with SIP and SRTP.
